if the migration is failed, then the Migration object should have a status being done, right?

If so, given we get all the evacuations by the ['accepted', 'done'] filters for the status, I'm not sure a done migration would be deleting the instance in the source if we merge your patch.
I'm confused, see my comment in PS2.

This patch tries to address the issues with unsuccessful migrations. When that happens the migration object status is still done but the VM has not successfully moved to destination host. That is what we are trying to address here.
In case of a successful migration/evacuate the VM's instance would get updated with the destination host and then we should be ok to delete the instance from source.
You're missing some unittest here for checking that.

nova/virt/vmwareapi/volumeops.py.message: if there is a storage profile which prevents moving the volume to the nova compute cluster then we should fail?
yes, good point. i need to check that.

I am not sure this is correct. I think we can have volume located on datastore A attached to host A and instance located on datastore B attached to host B. As long as datastores A and B are in the cluster managed by nova, we should be fine. The relocation is only necessary when the volume is on a datastore which is not in the compute cluster managed by Nova.


Why do we need this check in the first place? Why not always relocate if there is no SPBM policy for the volume?
we need to make sure that the instance is able to access the volume. this should only be possible if the host has access to the datastore. if not then the operation will fail

If the volume's datastore is not accessible, we should relocate irrespective of whether there is a policy or not. If there is a policy and the current datastore is not accessible, will the attach fail?

For VVOL datastores, there is a defult policy which will be returned even if there is no policy associated with the volume's volume type. So the following check will be True always for volumes in VVOL datastores.
I meant to say that the following check will be False.
We don't need these checks, you can directly call RelocateVM. If the volume VM is already on the correct datastore, the relocate operation will be no-op and will be executed fast.

the code above checks that the host of the instance is able to access the datastore that was selected by cinder. 
if not then we need to relocate to the datastore selected in vmops
that would require calling the relocate twice - the first time with the cinder datatsore and then catching an exception and then again with the vmops datastore
hence i think that we should go with the checks above
It seems like this is not tested?
It seems like this is not tested?

nova/virt/ironic/driver.py.message: Note for stable branches, this will have to take into account the value of CONF.workarounds.report_ironic_standard_resource_class_inventory because if we still report standard resource class inventory then we likely should still report the standard resource class allocations from the flavor - but I haven't thought too hard about it.
Does that mean they were already zeroed? Is it possible they're in extra_specs, but nonzero? (Would that just be a user error?)
I think I agree here. I would expect a non-zero value for vcpus to already be here for an older instance, right? Feels like we should check if it's 0.

This code runs on compute startup in a separate thread and builds a cache of which instances have been processed and migrated already. So either an instance hasn't been migrated and we catch it and migrate it here, or the instance was created from a flavor that was already properly setup per the ironic flavor docs:

https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/configure-nova-flavors.html

What do you mean? The bug is that we migrated older instances and set the custom resource class value in extra specs but did not zero out their standard resource classes in extra specs, which once you set report_ironic_standard_resource_class_inventory=False on stable branches makes the bug appear because we're no longer reporting standard resource class inventory but we'll be trying to report standard resource class allocations. This is for instances created with flavors before their standard resource classes were zeroed out.

(later)

Oh I get your guys' question now - if we've already migrated this instance and zeroed out the standard resource class. We don't want to hit that one again if we've already zeroed it. I'll add a test.

Oh right, this is extra_specs, so it shouldn't be set. Sorry, I was thinking of "regular" specs. My bad. But, per Eric's last comment, we probably want to check anyway, right?
 
 > Oh I get your guys' question now - if we've already migrated this
 > instance and zeroed out the standard resource class. We don't want
 > to hit that one again if we've already zeroed it. I'll add a test.

+1, good point.

What I was talking about is if they're in extra_specs but nonzero. Presumably because some operator set up their flavor that way for some reason? Perhaps that's their fault, but does the world explode as a result?

> What I was talking about is if they're in extra_specs but nonzero.
 > Presumably because some operator set up their flavor that way for
 > some reason? Perhaps that's their fault, but does the world explode
 > as a result?

IMHO, we shouldn't care if the user/operator sets a non-zero value through their flavor extra_specs. I mean its their fault like you said. I think we should only consider those ones that didn't migrate as far as this bug goes. Sure the world would explode for them but they did explicitly put the non-zero values after all.
Ditto, need to check if we're zeroed here, not that the key doesn't exist.
I am not sure why we need to check for the non-zero values.. am I missing something ?

My thought was along the lines of... if we know we're in a situation where things will explode, and we can fix it, why not?

I'm fine with a warning if we want to let it blow up, I just don't see why we wouldn't want to help the operator.

I don't think we would - we want to check if the standard resource class key exists in extra specs and if it's already 0, we consider that instance migrated; if it's non-zero, then I guess we log a warning and still consider it migrated.
I definitely like helping operators, but this code is temporary, right? Any help provided won't be around for long, so perhaps we shouldn't dwell on it.
This should probably be, "causes these resource classes to be filtered out from what is reported to placement".
We now shouldn't remove this code until Train, right?

At the earliest I guess yeah. We do have a nova-status upgrade check for the custom resource class migration:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e3c24da89aa3e6462f1b07e00659c87f252ba4ba/nova/cmd/status.py#L200

We shouldn't really drop this code until we're ready to drop that as well, and this might mean that check should also be updated to account for zeroed out standard resource classes.
Okay, let's update this docstring then.

IMO, this should be discussed, if user change the subnet to the service type which is not correct. For instance, change the subnet to the type of "network:floatingip_agent_gateway". Or change the subnet to which the in-use floating IPs can not work. Floating IP traffic may be down. This can indeed expand the neutron burden. One more thing, by default, ordinary user have no right to see the subnet type of the external network:


$ openstack network list
+--------------------------------------+---------+--------------------------------------+
| ID                                   | Name    | Subnets                              |
+--------------------------------------+---------+--------------------------------------+
| 18497185-f26d-4c1c-bf40-089b8941bea7 | public  | c0ddd56f-c344-4941-82c7-6ed26c4e7786 |
| 6b6519bf-9c96-4111-8a0b-a52e11c2ec1c | public2 |                                      |
+--------------------------------------+---------+--------------------------------------+
$ openstack subnet show c0ddd56f-c344-4941-82c7-6ed26c4e7786
No Subnet found for c0ddd56f-c344-4941-82c7-6ed26c4e7786

I can move the external interface of my router between subnets on the same network and still ping the floating IP, assuming I have a route to that subnet, as they are on the same network.  The only thing that might be different is you can't clear the router gateway now if a floating IP is attached (i.e. clearing the network), then set a new one, but you can change the subnet if you're the admin user, there isn't a validation method preventing this.

And regarding subnet service types, trying to change to an invalid service type does raise an error:

$ openstack router set --external-gateway public --fixed-ip subnet=d7272f79-7613-4ee8-9242-614fbd2d3261 router1
BadRequestException: 400: Client Error for url: http://10.18.57.7:9696/v2.0/routers/9e89ed85-261c-4482-95a6-88079f936a5f, Invalid input for operation: Failed to create port on network bda8f2c2-900b-4cb1-b259-fa891eab48b7, because fixed_ips included invalid subnet d7272f79-7613-4ee8-9242-614fbd2d3261.

Couple things here.

- I think this gets deleted instances. I assume those should have no `resources` (or if they do, they're not really claimed) so we might as well not retrieve them.
- use_slave doesn't seem to do anything. What were you expecting?
- Even long-term, the most common instance won't have any `resources`, so we could make this more efficient by adding a filter to only retrieve instances where `resources` IS NOT NULL. That might be a tweak for a followon.

But my biggest concern:

- Ew, we're grabbing *all* this host's instances *every* time we do a claim? That doesn't seem like a good plan. As noted in your TODO, we should cache -- but we should just cache the (claimed) resources, not the whole Instance (particularly because, as noted above, most Instances won't have any resources). And when we claim/unclaim, we update that cache (under lock). The initial setup of the cache can be done in the code path where you currently have _check_resources -- i.e. only triggered on startup.

I really don't like the fact that we're storing another copy of the provider tree.

After update_from_provider_tree finishes, self.provider_tree should be identical to self.reportclient._provider_tree. So we should simply be able to provide public access to the latter, perhaps via a reportclient @property.

This *would* be problematic because instance_claim and _move_claim can run asynchronously with _update_to_placement, so we would run the risk of getting the provider tree when it's in some intermediate state.

BUT

All of these methods are guarded by COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE, so we're guaranteed self.reportclient._provider_tree is in a consistent state while we're using it.

That said, I also don't like deliberately accessing the reportclient's cache.

What to do, what to do?

[Later]

Okay, how about this:

The uses of self.provider_tree are in _claim_resources and _check_resources. Both of those are read-only accesses of the .resources for a given provider. So let's make a method in SchedulerReportClient itself that returns just that. E.g.

 def local_resources_for_provider(self, rp_uuid):
     """Real docstring here."""
     return self._provider_tree.data(rp_uuid).resources

And then _claim_resources and _check_resources can simply ask for

 self.reportclient.local_resources_for_provider(rp_uuid)

and you don't need self.provider_tree in the resource tracker.

Sorry Luyao, you're right. I was willing to blur the line and have the report client be aware of the local resources - but I overlooked the fact that the report client's provider tree never sees them at all.

And self._provider_tree does not cache 'resources' now, we need to add a method, something like 'set_resources_for_provider', which will not be related to 'report to placement', just update _provider_tree. I'm not sure if it is proper.

I belive all DHCPv6 requests will have 'option6' and no 'option'. So these should be exclusive for each DHCP version.

> The rest of the revert code seems to be in the new conductor tasks so it might be better to move this there as well.

Do you mean the rollback stuff per task? You do have a point there. I believe the reason resize_instance for same-cell resize reverts the allocations on failure is because for same-cell resize as soon as conductor has cast to prep_resize on the dest compute, and prep_resize casts to resize_instance on the source compute, we're far from the revert code in the cold migration task in conductor:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/a8d2b24f1f9f801638b04c3140ccadfcd418fd55/nova/conductor/tasks/migrate.py#L321

However, for cross-cell resize we're in a synchronous RPC call from conductor so technically we could drop this code and eventually we should hit the revert in conductor (linked above). One issue would be if we lost the RPC connection so we can't get back to conductor, but that could cause lots of other issues as well, e.g. the decorators on this method might not work anyway if compute can't reach conductor to make changes to the DB.

Before removing this I'd want to make sure we have functional test coverage such that if something fails in this flow we'll properly revert the allocations.

I have a test like that for finish_snapshot_based_resize_at_dest failing:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/643451/

But not for prep_snapshot_based_resize_at_source failing. I'll add a patch for testing this in the functional test class and if it's cool I'll remove this.

Yeah I was just documenting what this flow explicitly raises, but for sure there could be lower-level things that bubble up, which is true of most things in the compute manager which don't even attempt to document themselves (our method documentation is historically pretty terrible).

 > But. Do you have a good reason listing InstancePowerOffFailure as
 > the only @messaging.expected_exceptions above? Is it somehow a
 > special exception?

expected_exceptions is for a list of, well, things you know can happen and shouldn't be traced by oslo.messaging. Anything not in the list would be considered "unexpected" and would get traced by oslo.messaging. If we have other things we hit coming from this frequently that are noise we can list those as well IMO. Having said all that, I seem to remember (it's been many months now) that at some point I had conductor explicitly handling InstancePowerOffFailure to check the power state and maybe try to recover the power state on the instance, but dropped that for whatever reason - probably because if you hit a failure at that point it's probably best to just reboot the instance.

 > 
 > Do we need a catch-all except block here to convert all the
 > possible exceptions to something generic, like MigrationError? Or
 > we have such a catch all on the client side already?

I'd rather not swallow and convert everything unexpected in case the caller wants/needs to do something different with the error handling at some point, but yes there is generic fault handling in the conductor code that will trigger a rollback of the task:

As you're aware since you diligently read up on _error_out_instance_on_exception (which I documented at some point because its usage is confusing), anything besides those exception types you pointed out will set the vm_state to error. I'm just passing STOPPED here because we know it's stopped and _error_out_instance_on_exception defaults to ACTIVE, so if that code eventually changes we don't have some weird bug where we fail and the instance power state is stopped but the vm_state goes back to ACTIVE (which is probably why I'm being explicit, because I worked on Ie4f9177f4d54cbc7dbcf58bd107fd5f24c60d8bb).

I guess you're just saying, the comment doesn't match the behavior so if we fail make sure the vm_status is ERROR regardless of the failure (NotImplementedError, InstanceFaultRollback), then yeah I suppose it should - I can see why the comment and the kwarg are confusing.

In the libvirt driver there is an overlapping code path between power_off() (triggered at L4719) and destroy() (called here). Both functions call nova.virt.libvirt.driver.LibvirtDriver._destroy(). I guess you still need both calls as power_off() gives you graceful shutdown of the instance and destroy() gives the possibility to unplug VIFs via cleanup(). 

I'm wondering if power_off() and driver.cleanup() would be enough. What do you think?

Oh also note that in same-cell resize, resize_instance (on the source compute) will call the driver's migrate_disk_and_power_off method which under the covers is very similar to what I'm doing here, which is power off the guest and then destroy the domain but retain the disks (in the case of reboot or revert for cross-cell resize). The difference from migrate_disk_and_power_off with cross-cell resize is we aren't transferring the disks to the dest host directly (via shared storage or ssh/rsync), we're leveraging the snapshot like shelve/unshelve.

I'm doing the power off and destroy separately because I want to stop the guest before doing a snapshot, which is similar to how shelve offload works - as noted in the commit message. Plus just because libvirt does different things with destroy doesn't mean other drivers are the same. Unless I'm misunderstanding what you're saying I should do.

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/635080/46/nova/compute/manager.py@5377

It also makes testing the various decorators separately from the rest of the meat of the operation simpler. In general it's something I've tried doing with this new stuff because of annoyances and cruft built up over the same-cell resize methods over the years, i.e. it is very cumbersome to unit test those existing methods because there is so much going on in one place. https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/0238cf431b021c8aa779848bb771222d7d8539cf/nova/conductor/tasks/migrate.py#L450

Because the migration.save will fail if it was deleted when the server was deleted (though maybe that migration.save doesn't fail and just updates a stale record in the source cell DB).

Anyway, if migration.save() doesn't fail we call revert_allocation_for_migration:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/0238cf431b021c8aa779848bb771222d7d8539cf/nova/conductor/tasks/migrate.py#L461

And that will swap the allocations held by the migration consumer on the source host back to the instance consumer which may already be deleted. We do use consumer generations for POST /allocations but it looks like we might pass consumer_generation=None if the target consumer (the instance in this case) does not exist:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/0238cf431b021c8aa779848bb771222d7d8539cf/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L1886

That will recreate the allocations for the instance on the source host using the allocations held by the migration consumer. And that's what I'm seeing in my recreate test - the server is gone from the source and target cell DBs but the source host still has allocations for the instance consumer because the migration task rollback swapped them back rather than just deleting them.

> What happens if I delete the instance while this is going on? We'll
 > abort here and start rolling things back, but will all of those
 > ports and allocations get cleaned up without choking on the deleted
 > instance? Thinking about this, it's a pretty precarious situation
 > to be in.. We've got instances and migrations in both cells right
 > now, allocations all over the place, and if we abort in the middle
 > due to a deleted instance and don't clean all that up properly
 > we're leaving quite a mess.

At this point the instance mapping still points at the instance in the source cell db so if the user deletes the instance concurrently it's going to delete the instance from the source cell DB along with cleaning up its ports/volumes/allocations as tracked in the source cell DB (and placement centrally for allocations).

On this specific line nothing will blow up because we're updating the target cell DB instance. We should blow up on L507 though since that is the instance in the source cell database, but I would have to test that since we're not specifying expected_task_state. I would expect save() to fail with InstanceNotFound or UnexpectedDeletingTaskStateError.

If this fails then we should rollback and cleanup the instance from the target cell DB and eventually MigrationTask should also try to revert the allocations, created by the scheduler, on the dest host.

 > 
 > Is there a test somewhere further up the stack that hits this
 > scenario?

I don't think I have a specific test for deleting the instance from the source while we're prepping on the dest, I do have some negative tests for things failing during the resize to the target cell and verifying that rebooting on the source fixes the status:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/643451/

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/669013/

I could add a negative test on top of those that does something like stub out the dest host resize_claim to delete the instance in the source cell (via the API so everything is kosher wrt DB handling) so that when we get back here in conductor and try to update the instance in the source cell it blows up and then assert we've cleaned up properly, e.g. no leaked allocations.

Yup I verified that the instance target consumer doesn't exist and we get a KeyError here when moving allocations back:

Maybe call the above 'Multi-cell topology' and then label this section `Multi-cell topology with shared cell controllers' to make it clear that you don't need to choose between these topologies?
Yeah, I meant some shared and some dedicated. For example if you had a few small cells, and then some really large ones. I suppose this can be discussed in follow up work.
You do need to choose though don't you? Or do you mean that you could have some shared and some dedicated?

To the uninitiated it might not be obvious why you would want to use this. Could we give an example, such as that you might want to do this if using cells as 'containers' for different racks of hardware, and in the case where the cells are small you may wish to share a cell controller?

Is this implying a HA setup, with, for example, the cell conductor for each cell running on each of the 3 cell controllers or should it just be a single cell controller hosting services for more than one cell? (I imagined the latter).
We already depend on the existing HAProxy for access to console proxies. At least there are multiple HAProxy instances. It probably needs some more thought.
Hmm, this would use the existing HAProxy? I suppose it depends on whether you want the cell to be the failure domain.

I added the replicas to show that HA is possible. It represents a set of controllers running the control services for the same set of cells. Without this you lose multiple cells by rebooting. It's actually another benefit of this approach - HA becomes more realistic.

We just need to be careful to spell out (when we get to it) that a cells mariadb can only live on one host. Of course that's another SPOF now I think of it. Perhaps we should revisit that limitation.
Won't we also support top level DB cluster + single node cell DB in the first iteration? Similar for Rabbit?
I wasn't planning on it. We have until Friday to get it merged, and this patch is pretty huge.
OK, I can look at adding it back in a follow up patch post Friday. Hopefully not too much effort as it was previously working.

Or just re-using what you have in the docs is good too:

"Name or ID of image(s) to cache."

it would be nice to transform `_find_image` to `_find_images` and use the whole power of glance listing API (it supports listing by several names[*]), so we can reduce the number of API calls.

[*] - https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/image/v2/?expanded=list-images-detail#list-images
Are you asking me to do that refactor before I can land this change?

> Client-side we'd have to validate that the number of images we get
 > back from glance is equal to the number provided or fail and when
 > failing we would have to figure out the difference (what is
 > missing?) so it's more complicated than just listing the images
 > since the listing API won't 404 if something is missing.

It is just a few lines of code:

   def find_images(self, names_or_ids):
        with self.alternate_service_type(
                'image', allowed_types=('image',)):
            matches = self._list('/v2/images?id=in:%s' % ','.join(names_or_ids))
            matches.extend(self._list('/v2/images?names=in:%s' % ','.join(names_or_ids)))
            missed = names_or_ids - set(m.name for m in matches) - set(m.id for m in matches)
            if missed:
                raise Exception()
            additional = set()
            for i in matches:
                 if i.name not in names_or_ids and i.uuid not in names_or_ids:
                     additional.add(i)
            if addtional:
                 raise Exceiption()

> Are you asking me to do that refactor before I can land this
 > change?

Unfortunately, my experience says that if I agree with doing it at follow up the patch, it will never happen :)
And I think that it is a real performance issue. If someone requests to cache 10 images, the current implementation will  make 10 separate API calls to Glance instead of just 2(maybe it is even one, I did not check the glance API for combination of searching by id and name)...

PS: I did not put -2, so I'm ok that others will ignore my comment.

I don't think that's probably reasonable in v1 of this, it could be a follow up optimization. Note that I also had that idea in the server side review:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/687139/4/nova/conductor/api.py@165

Client-side we'd have to validate that the number of images we get back from glance is equal to the number provided or fail and when failing we would have to figure out the difference (what is missing?) so it's more complicated than just listing the images since the listing API won't 404 if something is missing.

If there are a lot of images (>2) for the cache request, I agree with @Andrey's point of view that "_find_images" is necessary, which will reduce the number of calls to the glance API and improve performance. But if the requested image is small, comparing the two implementations, the performance loss here is almost negligible. It's just my personal opinion.

neutron/agent/linux/iptables_firewall.py.message: In a perfect world we'd have made ip_lib.sysctl() be smarter and take args/flags, but not worth a re-write yet to handle this

In ip_lib.sysctl(), apart from -w (write value), we should have -b (get value) and -N (print variable names).

I can handle this is a separate bug.

Right, it could take a flag, but default to -w to keep the current behavior.  The tricky part is making sure it returns the correct value as -w returns a bool currently.  Something to do on a slow Friday :)
I would say it's more like WARNING instead of INFO
here maybe debug would be enough?

Let me say that this is going to be printed only once, when the agent (and the FW) is initialized. Could be useful to have this information in the log by default (as INFO is the default log level).

But this is just my opinion.

IMHO it would be better to log differently in case when value is enabled and when it's not. If it's enabled we can just log on debug level as You proposed here but in case when it's disabled we should maybe log it in warning level and explain that with such setting security groups for ports will NOT work which is IMO important information for operator.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Do we know how it cover up other problems?

AFAIK, the "subtransactions" flag in begin() means that if there is already a transaction, nothing happens except a counter is incremented, else a new transaction is started.

The above mentioned counter is decremented when commit() is called and only when it  goes back to zero does the actual COMMIT happens.

I don't understand how this would result in inactive sessions.

> Do we know how it cover up other problems?

If there's still a transaction open that shouldn't be then starting a new one without subtransactions=True would fail immediately. With subtransactions=True the can gets kicked down the road and the failure may occur (if at all) at some later time when it's harder to track down the cause.

> AFAIK, the "subtransactions" flag in begin() means that if there is already a transaction, nothing happens except a counter is incremented, else a new transaction is started.

Effectively, yes.

> I don't understand how this would result in inactive sessions.

Me neither :)

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/helm/elastic.message: do we mean Gibibyte or Gigabyte here?

elasticsearch-curator size limit documentation refers to Gigabytes but I'm pretty certain it is actually Gib. Close enough to approximate a Gigabyte for a Gibibyte anyway for what we need to do here, and if curator does in fact use gigabytes it would just provide some additional headroom beyond the margin_factor below.
margin_factor can be applied to data_volume_size_b so it doesnt need to be recalculated again below thrice
Ok. Was going to have some logic for margin_factor based on index, but removed.  Will apply to data_volume_size_gb just the once.

nfv/nfv-vim/nfv_vim/host_fsm/_host_task_.message: I don't want to change this. If the host goes offline after the lock was issued and that prevents pods from terminating, I think that it is correct for us to fail the lock. The user can re-issue the lock if they like and it will succeed.
